channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Syrian Refugees in Jordan Struggle to Survive
item.description: More than half the 500,000 Syrian refugees in Jordan are under 18. “They can’t see beyond, frankly, the next day,” an aid worker says.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: U.S. Fears Russia May Sell Air Defenses to Syria
item.description: The delivery of the Russian S-300 missile batteries would represent a major qualitative advancement in Syria’s air defenses.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has benefited from the support of Iran and Russia.

item.title: Okinawa Piques Chinese Papers
item.description: Chinese state-run newspapers are questioning Japan’s sovereignty over the island, the latest sign of growing nationalism and territorial ambitions among China’s elite.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: New Fatal Fire at Bangladesh Clothes Maker
item.description: The fire late Wednesday at the Tung Hai Sweater Factory in Dhaka, the national capital, again raises questions about the safety of garment factories in Bangladesh.
item.category: Bangladesh Garment Manufacturers and Exporters Assn
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Bill Would Deny Iran Access to Foreign Exchange Reserves
item.description: A bipartisan group of senators introduced legislation that would deny the Iranian government access to its foreign-exchange reserves in the banks of other countries.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Boston Bombing Inquiry Looks Closely at Russia Trip
item.description: Officials are investigating reports that Tamerlan Tsarnaev, a suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings, may have tried to contact Islamist extremists.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Dagestani branch of the Russian Federal Security Service, via Reuters
item.media:description: The Canadian-born militant William Plotnikov, right, who died alongside Islamist insurgents last July in Dagestan.

item.title: Iran Hostages See Renewed Focus on Their Plight
item.description: After finding their captivity in Iran three decades ago seemingly forgotten, they now see hope in a 17-year battle for compensation.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: The just-released hostages in 1981, at an air base outside Frankfurt, on their way home.

item.title: Claude Guéant, a Sarkozy Ally, at Center of Corruption Allegations
item.description: The scandal involving Claude Guéant, a former interior minister, involves a bank transfer, two Flemish paintings and tens of thousands of dollars in cash payments.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: Ex-Aide to Medvedev and Putin Out at Kremlin
item.description: The former adviser, Vladislav Y. Surkov, had coined the phrase “sovereign democracy” to describe the new Russian system, with popular but closely manipulated elections.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Vladislav Y. Surkov, left, with then-prime minister Vladimir V. Putin last year.

item.title: Official Offers Account From Libya of Benghazi Attack
item.description: A veteran official gave a riveting account of the terrorist attack in Libya last Sept. 11 and described its contentious aftermath at a charged Congressional hearing that reflected weighty political stakes.
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.dc:creator: By JEREMY W. PETERS and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gregory Hicks, center, a State Department official, presented on Wednesday the first public testimony from an American official who was in Libya during the seige of the diplomatic compound in Benghazi last Sept. 11.

item.title: Argument to Overturn Detainee’s Conviction Cites Years in Custody Without a Trial
item.description: A lawyer for the only terrorist detainee to be held at the Guantánamo Bay prison and then tried in the civilian court system asked a federal appeals court to overturn his conviction.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Preparing for Watershed Elections in Pakistan
item.description: The general election, scheduled for Saturday, will signify the first time that a civilian government has served a full term and handed power to another elected administration.

item.title: Heritage Analyst’s Dissertation on Immigrant I.Q. Causes Furor
item.description: A day before a Senate committee was to take up a bill, a 2009 dissertation by a Heritage Foundation analyst added fuel to the debate.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By ASHLEY PARKER and JULIA PRESTON

item.title: Death Toll Passes 800 in Bangladesh Disaster
item.description: As more bodies were recovered from the wreckage, the government began distributing wages and other benefits to those who had worked in the building.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Israel Moves to End Gender Segregation in Public Spaces
item.description: The attorney general called on public agencies “to act fast, efficiently and decisively” on sweeping new rules after years of legal battles over the treatment of women.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Court Upholds Berlusconi Tax Fraud Verdict
item.description: An appeals court in Milan sentenced former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi to four years in prison and imposed a five-year ban on his holding public office.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Stolen Diamonds Are Recovered in Raids Across Europe
item.description: The raids rounded up more than 30 people and recovered some of the $50 million in diamonds stolen in a Brink’s armored car robbery in Brussels in February.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: In Pakistan, Patronage’s Roots Run Deep
item.description: Amid the talk of change in Saturday’s elections, Pakistan remains a place where handouts can decide votes and lawmakers are sought out for protection.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yousaf Raza Gilani, a former prime minister, is credited with improving infrastructure in Pakistan during his time in office.

item.title: Rally Turns Deadly in Southern Afghanistan
item.description: Local officials greatly differed in their accounts of how violence started at an event that was said to have begun as a peaceful pro-government rally.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Prospect of Iran’s Election Stirs Little Hope This Time Around
item.description: In the run-up to the June 14 presidential election, the enthusiasm of 2009 has been replaced, for now at least, with an indifference bred of fear.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Iranian officials register for the June 14 presidential elections.

item.title: News Analysis: China Dips a Toe Into Mideast Diplomacy
item.description: Back-to-back visits from the Palestinian and Israeli leaders hinted that China had given some thought to playing a more energetic, if very limited, role as mediator.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping with Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian Authority leader, in Beijing.

item.title: Amalfi Journal: On Amalfi Coast, the Business of Lemons
item.description: On the Amalfi Coast, a family’s bid to keep its small business going mirrors Italy’s debate about keeping local traditions alive in a global economy.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:description: The Amalfi Coast is known these days as a tourist mecca.

item.title: Next W.T.O. Head Wants a New Look at the Body’s Role
item.description: Robert Carvalho de Azevêdo, the next head of the World Trade Organization, said the institution should adapt as nations seek more regional trade agreements.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Stephen Hawking Joins Boycott Against Israel
item.description: Dr. Hawking, a renowned physicist and cosmologist, will not attend an annual conference on the future of Israel and the Jewish people.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Britain Moves to Toughen Rules on Immigrants
item.description: The proposed changes announced Wednesday by the dominant Conservatives followed sharp gains in local elections last week by a populist party that wants to curb migration.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
